items.title: jsonlines.Writer encoding an alternative codec to UTF-8
items.body:
Feature suggestion:

Enable the `jsonlines.Writer.write(self, obj)` to receive another parameter - encoding which allows the user to specify the output encoding.

Right now reading the output.jsonl filethat I dumped, looks as follows:

>  President Trump was seeking the \u201cultimate deal\u2014 in the Middle East 

What I would like to see:

>  President Trump was seeking the “ultimate deal” in the Middle East

items.body:
Hi! Sorry to ask this here, but I find it hard to see differences. is there a different problem this is solving, or feature comparison vs. this package:

https://github.com/TeamHG-Memex/json-lines

items.title: ModuleNotFound error even after installing jsonlines
items.body:
I am getting ModuleNotFound error even after installing jsonlines. I am trying to run the python program (Python 3.6) using JupyterLab in AWS SageMaker. Here are the steps. Can you please help?

1) Install jsonlines
!pip install jsonlines

2) Import jsonlines library
import jsonlines

3) Error occurred
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ModuleNotFoundError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-0bb7078641ac> in <module>()
      6 
      7 import boto3
----> 8 import jsonlines
      9 import matplotlib
     10 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'jsonlines'

items.title: Can't create JSONL file on Jupyter
items.body:
Hi everyone, 
I created list of lists, then trsansformed it to dataframe afterwards transformed it to JSONL string, plz see the code below:

```python
lst_revs3 = []
for i in lst_revs2:
    m = [i,str(random.randint(1,3))]
    lst_revs3.append(m)
print(lst_revs3[0:5])

df = pd.DataFrame(lst_revs3, columns = ['review','label'])

jsl = df.to_json(orient='records', lines=True)
```

My question is how to create file with jsonl extension which contains the jsl data?
this is necessary for parsing this file to google AUTOML NLP

items.title: idea: method to load jsonlines file to list
items.body:
Hi,

Love the library. We're starting to use jsonlines as our de-facto format for storing datasets for data science, since it's useful for streaming and batch processing. What this means is that all the json objects in a given file are homogeneous, and we almost always want to load the objects into a list in Python. 

We've currently got our own (super simple) function to do this, but I imagine this is quite a common use-case so would be good for the library to have something like a `Reader().to_list()` function. 

What do you think? Happy to implement this and make a PR if you think it's a good idea.

items.title: incomplete iteration when given list containing empty strings
items.body:
``` python
>>> import jsonlines

>>> list(jsonlines.Reader(['123', '456', '', '789']))
[123, 456]
```

this should raise an error instead since `''` is not a valid json value, and `skip_empty` defaults to `False`.

for normal files it works as expected:

``` python
>>> list(jsonlines.Reader(io.StringIO('123\n456\n\n789')))
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
InvalidLineError: line contains invalid json: Expecting value: line 2 column 1 (char 1) (line 3)

>>> list(jsonlines.Reader(io.StringIO('123\n456\n\n789')).iter(skip_empty=True))
[123, 456, 789]
```

items.title: How is this module useful?
items.body:
Hi,

I don't see how this 350-line library is better than `map(json.loads, f)` and `print(json.dumps(...), file=f)`, where `f` is a file object opened with `encoding='utf-8'`. As far as I can tell, the `map` and `print` solutions are fully compatible with [the jsonlines standard](http://jsonlines.org/).

Thanks.

items.title: Specify BSD license type / Add copy to repo
items.body: Per pypi and the metadata, `jsonlines` is licensed under a BSD license but it's unclear which one  - the two- or the three-clause. Going by the information in the [documentation](https://jsonlines.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#license), it's the three-clause, but would you consider adding a copy of the license to the repository itself? It'd also be helpful if you added a `MANIFEST.in` with an `include LICENSE.txt` line so that copies of the license get included in future source tarballs. Thanks!

items.title: also allow string forms for the `type=` argument
items.body:
in addition to passing `...(type=dict)` (passing the type itself), something like `...(type='dict')` (passing the name of the type) may be useful.

not entirely convinced, but passing types may be confusing for choice-like flags.

items.title: Make jsonlines.open() accept a data stream from network
items.body:
Code Snippet:

```python
r = requests.get(<some-url>)
with jsonlines.open(r.content.decode()) as reader:
    for line in reader:
        print(line)
```

Expected Result:

```
Parsing every line as individual JSON object.
```

Current Result:

```
Can't read the network stream
```

Please let me know if such a feature can be included. If yes, I would love to talk and submit a PR.

items.title: rename fp arg to reader
items.body: since it takes more than just file names now that #16 has been implemented

items.title: custom `dump` function
items.body: a custom `dump` function (instead of `dumps`) that writes directly to the file-like object might be sensible for performance reasons. it would be mutually exclusive with the `dump` arg.

items.title: simplify i/o by getting rid of iowrappers
items.body:
get rid of the io wrappers, which would simply the code
- input should just be an iterable of strings #16 
- output
  - `.write()` takes unicode or byte string; check by writing empty string and catching `TypeError`
  - `.flush()` only called when told so

`.close()` on the underlying file-like object is only used by our own `open()` so that can be handled internally (no public API)

items.title: compare to ndjson
items.body: ...and maybe mention it in the docs

items.title: include line number in exception string
items.body:
...so that by default the messages point to the right location, e.g. "something went wrong (line 12)".

the number is alread programatically available from the exception's `lineno` attribute.

items.title: make the reader accept any iterable yielding strings
items.body:
perhaps it makes sense to make the reader except any iterable that yields strings (which includes lists and file like objects) instead of requiring a file object.

the stdlib's csv module does something similar.

items.title: keep track of line numbers
items.body: ...and embed those in exception messages and as a `.line` attribute on the exception instance

items.title: support custom json encoding/decoding libraries
items.body: perhaps some hooks can be provided, defaulting to the stdlib's `json` module.

items.title: add api to read objects of a specific type
items.body: e.g. `read_dict()`, `read_number()`, `read_int()`, and so on

items.title: support custom json encoding flags
items.body: e.g. `sort_keys`

items.title: rename dump/load to write/read
items.body: ...which are better names for writer/reader objects

items.title: proper documentation
items.body: This project should have proper Sphinx documentation.

items.title: add api to obtain or ignore invalid lines
items.body: e.g. for reading json-formatted log files with interspersed non-json lines

items.title: add support for restricting the type of objects being returned
items.body: e.g. only allow dicts (json objects) instead of any json type.

items.title: implement .write_all()
items.body: follow-up on #3

items.title: Support flushing after each doc in dumper
items.body: the writer could have a `flush=True` arg that will `.flush()` the fp after each write.

items.title: dumping support
items.body:
both a `.dump()` for dumping a single item and a `.dump_all()` that consumes an iterable.

Perhaps a `Writer` style API makes sense (cf. `csv` module).

items.title: loading support
items.body:
Generator style loading:

``` python
for obj in jsonlines.load(fp):
    # pass
```

It should handle both file-like objects opened in binary (byte strings) and unicode (text) modes.

Perhaps a `Reader` style API makes more sense (cf. `csv` module).
